What type of paint should I use for bathroom walls?

For bathroom walls you want a paint that stands up to frequent humidity, temperature swings and the occasional splash. Here’s what to look for and why:

1. Base: 100 % acrylic latex (water-based).  
   • Fast drying, low odour and easy clean-up.  
   • Flexible film resists cracking and peeling caused by moisture.

2. Finish (sheen):  
   • Satin or Semi-gloss are the sweet spots for bathrooms.  
     – They’re tight-pored enough to repel water and allow easy wiping, but not as shiny as a full gloss.  
   • Matte/eggshell can work only if specifically labelled “bathroom” or “bath & kitchen” and contains extra mildewcide.

3. Mildew- & mould-resistant additives:  
   • Look for wording such as “mould-block”, “mildewcide”, “bath & kitchen”, or “moisture-resistant”.  
   • These inhibit fungal growth on the paint film—important in a damp environment.

4. Primer:  
   • If you have new drywall, patched areas, or are changing from oil-based to latex, apply a quality moisture-resistant primer first.  
   • Many “bathroom paints” are paint-and-primer-in-one; still spot-prime repairs and stains for best results.

5. VOC level:  
   • Choose low- or zero-VOC formulas for healthier indoor air, especially in rooms without large windows.

Typical options we stock at Zava:

• ZavaPro Bath-Shield Satin (interior acrylic, mildew-resistant)  
• ZavaPro Ultra Semi-Gloss (paint + primer, 0 g/L VOC)  
• Benjamin Moore Aura Bath & Spa Matte (for those who want a low-sheen look without sacrificing moisture resistance)  
• Zinsser Perma-White Interior Satin (self-priming, antimicrobial)

Application tips:

1. Scrub the walls with a degreaser or a 3:1 water-and-vinegar mix; let dry.  
2. Repair and sand any dings, then wipe off dust.  
3. Mask, cover fixtures, and ensure good airflow (fan/door open).  
4. Prime if needed; let dry per label.  
5. Roll on two thin coats of your bathroom paint, waiting the recommended re-coat time.  
6. Allow 48 hours cure before hot showers to give the film time to harden.

Following these guidelines will give you a wipe-clean, mildew-resistant finish that stays looking fresh for years. If you’d like more detail on colour selection, quantities or tools, just let me know!

What's a professional-grade paint tray?

A professional-grade paint tray is a step up from the inexpensive, disposable trays often sold in multipacks. Contractors and serious DIYers use them because they’re built to survive repeated clean-ups, resist harsh solvents, and hold more paint without flexing or tipping. While every brand is a little different, most pro-level trays share these characteristics:

1. Heavy-duty construction  
   • Material: Either 24–30 ga. galvanized steel or thick, solvent-resistant polypropylene/HDPE.  
   • Reinforced rails to keep the tray from warping when fully loaded.

2. Larger paint reservoir  
   • Holds 1¼–1½ quarts (≈1.2–1.4 L) so you reload the roller less often.  
   • Steeper walls reduce splash-out.

3. Integrated, full-depth ribbed roll-off area  
   • Deeper ribs give better paint distribution across the roller sleeve.  
   • Often textured to prevent the roller from “hydroplaning.”

4. Stable footing  
   • Wide base or snap-on, non-skid feet so the tray doesn’t slide on drop cloths.  
   • Some metal versions include a wire bail handle that doubles as a leg for angling the tray on stairs.

5. Liner compatibility  
   • Sized to accept rigid or disposable liners, letting you switch colors without a full wash-down.  
   • Liners are typically numbered: a “14-in.” tray takes a “14-in.” liner, etc.

6. Solvent and chemical resistance  
   • Safe for oil-based enamels, epoxy primers, denatured-alcohol stains, and aggressive brush cleaners.  
   • Won’t soften or pit when left to soak overnight.

7. Accessory ports or hooks (on some models)  
   • Clip points for attaching a tray cover during lunch breaks.  
   • End hooks so you can hang the tray from a ladder rung.

How to choose the right one:

• Match the tray width to your roller frame (most pros use 9-in., but 12-in. and 14-in. “jumbo” trays exist).  
• Decide on weight vs. durability. Steel is nearly indestructible but heavier; thick HDPE is lighter and rust-proof.  
• If you work on ladders or scaffolding, look for trays with a built-in hook or a magnetic brush rest.  
• If you spray and back-roll, choose a deep-well tray (2+ quarts) to keep up with high production rates.

Popular professional lines at Zava:

• Linzer “Pro-Edge” 9-in. steel tray (#TR-PE9)  
• Wooster “Magnum” 14-in. polypropylene tray (#WT-MG14)  
• Purdy “Dura-Press” 9-in. HDPE tray with locking liners (#PD-DP9)  

Care & maintenance tips:

1. Scrape excess paint back into the can before washing.  
2. Flush with warm water (latex) or the proper solvent (oil-based), then follow with dish soap.  
3. Dry completely to prevent rust on steel models.  
4. Store liners nested inside the tray so they keep their shape.

A professional-grade tray costs more up front—typically US $8–17 for heavy plastic and US $15–25 for galvanized steel—but it can last for years or even decades when used with liners. If you have any other paint-gear questions or need to compare specific models, let us know and we’ll be glad to help.

How do I match existing wall paint?

Matching existing wall paint can take a little detective work, but with the right approach you can get very close—often spot-on. Here’s a step-by-step guide you can follow before you head to Zava or any other paint counter:

1. Gather Information You Already Have  
   • Check old paint cans or project notes. Look for the brand, color name/number, sheen (e.g., eggshell, satin), and the formula printed on the lid or can label.  
   • Ask the builder or previous homeowner if they kept records. A quick phone call or email can save time.

2. Inspect the Wall in Good, Natural Light  
   • Different lighting (morning sun vs. evening lamp) can make the paint appear warmer or cooler. Note what time of day the room is used most; that’s the lighting under which you want the match to look right.  
   • Clean the area gently with a mild soap solution and let it dry first. Dust or film can slightly change perceived color.

3. Decide on a Matching Method  
   A. Bring a Sample to the Store  
   • Cut a chip: Carefully score a 1×1 inch section with a utility knife in an inconspicuous spot (behind a switch plate or baseboard). The drywall paper is thin; aim to peel the paint layer only.  
   • If the wall is plaster or you’d rather not remove paint, unscrew a faceplate or vent cover—sometimes the back side has untouched original paint you can bring.  
   • Place the chip in a small plastic bag to protect it from scratching in your pocket or purse.

   B. Use In-Store Color Matching Instruments  
   • Most Zava locations have a spectrophotometer. We’ll scan your sample and generate a custom formula in minutes.  
   • The result is typically within ±1–2 ΔE (a very small human-perceivable difference) if the sample is clean and at least ½×½ inch.

   C. Try Digital Apps (Secondary Option)  
   • Phone-camera color apps can be helpful for narrowing choices, but phone sensors and screen calibration vary. Treat app results as a starting point—not the final answer.

4. Choose the Same Sheen  
   • Even a perfect color match can look off if the gloss level differs. Bring or note the finish: flat, matte, eggshell, satin, semi-gloss, or gloss.  
   • If you’re unsure, hold a flashlight at a low angle across the wall; more reflected glare means higher sheen.

5. Buy or Mix a Small Test Quantity  
   • Ask for a sample pot (8 oz or 1 pint). It’s inexpensive and lets you confirm the match before committing to a gallon.  
   • Label the lid with date, room, and formula for future reference.

6. Perform a Test Patch  
   • Feather out a thin, 12×12 cm (5×5 in) square on the wall. Blend edges lightly with a mini roller or dry brush.  
   • Let it fully dry (color can shift slightly as water/solvent evaporates). Check under day and night lighting.

7. Blend or Recoat Entire Sections if Needed  
   • If the color is close but not seamless, repaint from natural breakpoints (inside corners, trim lines) to disguise minor variances.  
   • Large repairs or sun-faded walls often need a full-wall or full-room coat for best results.

8. Store Leftover Paint Properly  
   • Label the can (room, date, and formula). Seal it tightly, wipe the rim, and store in a climate-stable spot—ideally 50–90 °F.  
   • Well-sealed paint can last 5–10 years, making future touch-ups easier.

Safety and Extras  
• Lead paint: If the home predates 1978 in the U.S., be cautious when cutting paint chips. Use a lead test swab or consult a professional if uncertain.  
• Patch repair: If you removed a chip larger than a fingernail, spackle, sand, and prime that spot before touch-up.  
• Roller nap matters: Use the same nap length (¼", ⅜", etc.) you originally used—different textures can catch light differently.

Need help? Bring your chip or at least a high-resolution photo of your wall (in daylight) to your nearest Zava Paint Desk. We’ll scan, mix, and send you home with a color you’ll be proud to roll on.

How do I paint over chalkboard paint?

Painting over an existing chalkboard surface is straightforward—you just need to neutralise the chalk residue, create a key for new paint to bond, and apply the right primer and topcoat. Here is a step-by-step guide:

1. Clear the surface  
   • Wipe off all loose chalk with a dry cloth or chalkboard eraser.  
   • Wash the wall with warm water and a mild detergent (sugar soap, dishwashing liquid or Zava’s Multi-Surface Cleaner). Rinse with clean water.  
   • Let the surface dry completely.

2. Lightly sand  
   • Use 120–150-grit sandpaper or a fine sanding sponge.  
   • Scuff just enough to dull the sheen and knock down any writing grooves.  
   • Wipe away dust with a damp microfibre cloth or tack cloth.

3. Spot-fill (if needed)  
   • If there are scratches, nail holes or dents, fill with a ready-mixed filler.  
   • Allow to dry, then sand smooth and dust off again.

4. Prime the surface  
   • Apply one coat of a stain-blocking or multi-surface primer (e.g. Zava Multi-Surface Primer/Sealer or any quality acrylic primer).  
   • A primer is essential—it seals in chalk pigments and gives your finish coat an even appearance.  
   • Follow the tin’s drying times; most primers are ready for recoating after 1–2 hours.

5. Apply the finish coat  
   • Choose any interior wall paint (matt, eggshell or satin). Chalkboard paint is dark, so you may need two coats for full hide—three if you’re going from black to a very light colour.  
   • Cut in with a 50 mm (2″) angled brush, then roll the larger areas with a 10–12 mm nap roller for smooth walls.  
   • Maintain a wet edge to avoid lap marks. Allow the first coat to dry fully (per the manufacturer’s instructions) before the second coat.

6. Clean up  
   • Wash brushes and rollers in warm, soapy water if you used water-based products.  
   • Peel off or score tape while the final coat is still slightly damp for the sharpest line.

Tips and troubleshooting  
• Tannin-rich woods (cedar, redwood) or previously “primed” chalkboards may need an extra bonding or stain-blocking primer.  
• If the old chalkboard surface feels highly slick, bump up to 180-grit sandpaper for a slightly coarser key.  
• Painting over magnetic chalkboard paint is the same process, but test your chosen primer on a small area—the magnetism can drop slightly once you add layers.

Recommended Zava supplies  
• Zava Multi-Surface Cleaner  
• 120- and 150-grit sanding sponges  
• Zava Multi-Surface Primer/Sealer  
• Zava Premium Interior Acrylic in your chosen sheen and colour  
• 50 mm angled sash brush + 230 mm low-nap roller set

If you have any questions about colour match, primer choice or tool selection, stop by the Paint desk or give us a call—we’ll be happy to help.

What's the best way to paint shiplap walls?

Here’s a proven, DIY-friendly process that professional painters often follow for shiplap. Adjust to suit your own project, but if you work through these steps in order you’ll get crisp lines, full coverage in the grooves, and a durable finish.

1. Gather the right supplies  
   • Orbital sander or sanding block (150–180-grit paper)  
   • Wood filler and putty knife  
   • Painter’s caulk and caulk gun  
   • Tack cloth or microfiber cloth  
   • Quality stain-blocking primer (especially for knotty pine)  
   • 2–2½" angled sash brush (for grooves and edges)  
   • 4–6" mini roller with a smooth, shed-resistant cover (¼"–⅜" nap) or a low-pressure HVLP sprayer  
   • High-quality interior acrylic-latex paint in your desired sheen (eggshell or satin are most common; semi-gloss if you want extra wipe-ability)  
   • Painter’s tape, drop cloths, step stool/ladder

2. Prep the surface (the most important step)  
   a. Light sanding: Scuff the boards just enough to remove glaze, mill marks, and any raised grain.  
   b. Dust removal: Wipe down thoroughly so primer can bond.  
   c. Fill nail holes: Press wood filler slightly proud of the surface. Let it dry, sand smooth, and dust again.  
   d. Caulk strategic gaps: Run a thin bead where the shiplap meets walls, ceilings, or trim. Skip the horizontal gaps between boards unless they’re letting light through—you want to keep that shadow line.

3. Prime thoroughly  
   • Brush primer into the grooves first, then roll/spray the flat faces.  
   • Stain-blocking primer is crucial on raw pine or any boards with knots to prevent tannin bleed.  
   • Allow full dry time, then do a quick, light sand (220-grit) to knock down fibers and dust off again.

4. Apply finish paint—two thin coats  
   First Coat  
   • Cut in grooves/edges: Use the angled brush, working the paint in both directions to coat the tongues and avoid missed spots.  
   • Roll or spray the faces: Keep a wet edge to avoid lap marks. Work top-to-bottom for consistency.  
   • Check for drips in the grooves; smooth them out before they set.  
   Second Coat  
   • After the first coat is fully dry, inspect and lightly sand any rough spots.  
   • Repeat the brush-and-roll routine. The second coat evens out sheen and hides any primer show-through.

5. Watch environmental conditions  
   • Ideal painting temps: 50–85 °F (10–30 °C).  
   • Low humidity speeds curing and reduces the chance of flashing (uneven sheen).

6. Let it cure before heavy use  
   • Latex feels dry to the touch in a few hours, but full cure can take 7–14 days. During that time, avoid pushing furniture directly against the boards or wiping aggressively.

Extra tips  
• If you prefer rustic “nickel-gap” lines, choose brushes/rollers sized to keep paint out of the recesses or run painter’s tape in the grooves and remove it while the paint is still wet.  
• Spraying can be faster on large expanses, but masking takes longer. If you’re rolling, a smaller nap (¼") gives a smoother, almost sprayed look.  
• For existing, glossy shiplap, use a chemical deglosser or a bonding primer (sometimes labeled “adhesion primer”) before painting.

Follow those steps and you’ll end up with a smooth, durable finish that still shows the classic shadow line that makes shiplap so distinctive. Happy painting, and if you need specific product recommendations or tool rentals, just let us know!

How do I paint over a dark color with a light one?

Here’s a reliable, store-tested approach for getting a light paint color to cover a dark one smoothly and evenly:

1. Clean the surface  
   • Wash the walls with warm water and a small amount of mild detergent (or a TSP substitute).  
   • Rinse with clean water and let dry completely.  
   • Remove any dust or cobwebs—good adhesion starts with a clean surface.

2. Repair and sand  
   • Fill nail holes or small dings with a lightweight spackling compound; let it dry and sand flush.  
   • Lightly scuff-sand the entire surface (120–150-grit) to knock down sheen and create tooth for the new coatings.  
   • Wipe away sanding dust with a damp cloth or tack cloth.

3. Choose the right primer  
   • Use a high-hide, stain-blocking primer—look for labels that say “high hiding,” “stain blocking,” or “for drastic color changes.”  
   • If the old paint is oil-based or very glossy, pick a bonding primer or de-gloss first.  
   • Tinting the primer toward your new color can reduce the number of finish coats needed; most Zava paint desks can tint primer for you.

4. Apply the primer correctly  
   • Cut in around edges with a quality angled brush.  
   • Roll the larger areas using a ⅜- to ½-inch nap roller (⅜″ for smooth drywall, ½″ for lightly textured walls).  
   • Lay the primer on generously enough to cover, but avoid thick, drippy coats.  
   • Let dry according to the label—typically 1–3 hours for water-based primers, 4+ for some stain blockers.

5. Inspect and spot-prime  
   • Once dry, look for dark “shadows” or patchy areas and hit them with a quick second coat of primer if necessary.  
   • Perform a fingernail scratch test—if the primer scratches off easily, let it cure longer.

6. Apply the light topcoat  
   • Stir the paint thoroughly.  
   • Work in the same cut-in/roll pattern as the primer.  
   • Maintain a wet edge to avoid lap marks—roll in roughly 3×3-foot sections, then back-roll lightly in one direction.  
   • Expect two finish coats for uniform coverage; very light colors (whites, pastels) may need a third, especially over reds or navies.

7. Dry and cure  
   • Allow recommended dry time between coats (usually 2–4 hours for latex).  
   • Wait at least 7 days before washing the walls so the paint film can harden fully.

Extra tips  
• Quality tools matter: a good microfiber roller sleeve and a tapered, synthetic-bristle brush leave fewer marks and cover better.  
• Keep lighting consistent—strong side lighting can reveal missed spots.  
• Maintain room temperature (around 65–80 °F / 18–27 °C) and moderate humidity for proper drying.

Shopping list at Zava  
• High-hide stain-blocking primer (water-based or oil-based, depending on existing surface)  
• Interior latex paint in your light color (eggshell, satin, etc.)  
• 120–150-grit sandpaper or sanding sponge  
• Lightweight spackle and putty knife  
• ⅜″–½″ nap roller covers, 9″ frame, paint tray  
• 2″ or 2-½″ angled brush  
• Painter’s tape, drop cloths, cleaning supplies

Bring a small chip of your existing color if possible; we can check whether it’s oil or latex and tint your primer while you wait. Let me know if you’d like product recommendations or coverage estimates!

What brushes work best for detailed trim work?

For crisp, controlled lines on window/door trim, crown moulding, baseboards and other detailed profiles, look for the following features:

1. Size & Shape  
   • 1″–2″ Angled Sash Brush – The slightly cut-in (beveled) edge lets you “cut” a straight line against the trim while keeping the ferrule clear of the surface.  
   • 1″ Flat Trim/Touch-up Brush – Handy for very thin lattice, muntins or ornate corners.  

2. Bristle Type  
   • Synthetic (nylon or nylon-polyester blend) for water-based/latex paints – holds shape, cleans up easily.  
   • Natural white China bristle for oil-based enamels or varnish – softer tips lay down a very smooth finish.  

3. Filament Quality  
   • Tapered, flagged (split-end) bristles carry more paint yet release it evenly.  
   • A stainless-steel ferrule crimped tightly to a hardwood handle lasts longest.  

4. Ergonomics  
   • Short, sash-style (rattail) or stubby handles give you better control in tight spots.  
   • A rubber-grip or hour-glass handle reduces fatigue during long sessions.

Popular, pro-grade options at Zava  
• Purdy XL Dale 1½″ Angled Sash (latex/oil)  
• Wooster Shortcut 1″ or 2″ Angled Sash (latex; flexible short handle)  
• Zibra Grip-N-Glide Triangle Detail Brush (good for intricate profiles)  
• Zava ProFinish 1½″ White China Bristle Trim Brush (oil-based enamels)

Application tips  
• Dip only the first ½ of the bristles; tap (don’t wipe) on the can’s inside to keep paint toward the tips.  
• Start ⅛″ away from the line, then draw the brush toward the cut-in edge to prevent lap marks.  
• Feather out the final stroke in one direction for a glass-smooth finish.  
• Keep a damp (latex) or solvent-moistened (oil) rag handy to quickly erase any over-brushing.

Using a high-quality, well-kept trim brush makes the difference between “good enough” and showroom-sharp trim lines. Happy painting!

How do I paint a laminate kitchen table?

Painting a laminate-covered table is completely doable—as long as you use the right prep, primer and paint. Below is a step-by-step guide you can follow with supplies you can pick up at any Zava DIY Hardware store.

–––––
Tools & Materials
1. Drop cloth and painter’s tape  
2. Household cleaner or degreaser (Zava Citrus-Clean or similar)  
3. 120- to 150-grit sanding sponge  
4. Lint-free tack cloth  
5. Bonding/adhesion primer for slick surfaces (e.g., Zinsser BIN Advanced, INSL-X STIX)  
6. High-quality latex, acrylic enamel, or alkyd-hybrid furniture paint  
7. ¼" microfiber or high-density foam roller, 1–2″ sash brush  
8. Optional: Water-based polyurethane or furniture wax for a top-coat  
9. Nitrile gloves, dust mask

–––––
Step-by-Step

1. Clear & Protect  
   • Remove any leaves, hardware or drop-in extensions.  
   • Lay down a drop cloth and tape off anything you don’t want painted.

2. Clean Thoroughly  
   • Laminate is non-porous and holds onto oils. Wash with a degreaser, rinse, and let dry.  
   • Any cleaner residue can keep paint from bonding, so wipe twice if necessary.

3. Lightly Scuff-Sand  
   • Using a 120- to 150-grit sanding sponge, scuff the entire laminate surface until it loses its glossy look.  
   • You’re not trying to expose wood—just creating microscopic scratches for the primer to grip.

4. Remove Dust  
   • Vacuum or wipe with a damp rag, then go over everything with a tack cloth.  
   • Dust left behind = peeling later.

5. Apply Bonding Primer  
   • Stir (don’t shake) the primer to avoid bubbles.  
   • Using a foam roller for the flat top and a brush for edges/legs, lay on a thin, even coat.  
   • Let it self-level; resist over-brushing.  
   • Most adhesion primers need 45–60 minutes to dry to the touch and 4–6 hours to cure enough for sanding or paint—check the can.

6. Light Sand & Clean Again  
   • After primer dries, do a very light pass with a 220-grit sanding pad to knock down nibs.  
   • Tack cloth off the dust.

7. Paint (2–3 Coats)  
   • Apply your chosen paint in thin, even layers with the foam roller; tip off edges with the sash brush.  
   • Allow recommended dry time (usually 4–6 h for latex, 12–16 h for alkyd hybrids) before recoating.  
   • Light sand between coats for an ultra-smooth finish.

8. Optional Protective Top-Coat  
   • For a kitchen table that sees heavy use, seal with 2–3 coats of water-based polyurethane (satin or semi-gloss).  
   • Allow at least 24 h after the last paint coat before clear-coating.  
   • If you prefer a soft, low-sheen finish, furniture wax works too but will need periodic re-application.

9. Cure Time  
   • “Dry” and “cured” are different. Avoid heavy use for about 7 days so the finish can fully harden.

–––––
Extra Tips

• Temperature & Humidity: Work between 50 °F and 85 °F (10–29 °C) and < 60 % humidity for best adhesion and leveling.  
• Brush Marks: A paint additive like Floetrol (for latex) or Penetrol (for alkyd) can extend open time and reduce brush strokes.  
• Color Changes: Dark-to-light transitions may need a tinted primer or an additional coat of paint.  
• Touch-Ups: Keep a small labeled jar of your mixed paint for future nicks and scratches.

–––––
Common Pitfalls to Avoid

✘ Skipping the scuff-sand: Primer may still peel on a glossy, un-etched laminate.  
✘ Thick coats: They dry on the surface but stay soft underneath, leading to dents and impressions.  
✘ Using regular wood primer: It usually won’t adhere well to the melamine/plastic surface of laminate.

–––––
Need Supplies or Advice?

Drop by your local Zava DIY Hardware; we stock all the primers, furniture paints, rollers and sanding pads mentioned above. Bring a photo of your table and one of our paint-desk teammates will help you choose the best color and sheen.

Happy painting, and enjoy your “new” kitchen table!

What's the best way to paint a metal shed?

Painting a metal shed is mostly about surface preparation and using the right coatings. Follow these steps and you’ll get a finish that looks good and lasts years.

1. Check the weather  
   • Work on a dry day with temperatures between 10 °C and 30 °C (50 – 86 °F).  
   • Avoid painting in direct intense sun or when rain is forecast within 24 hours.

2. Gather supplies  
   • Wire brush or drill-mounted wire wheel  
   • 120- to 220-grit sandpaper or sanding sponge  
   • Mild detergent (or TSP) and a bucket  
   • Clean water and rags  
   • Rust converter (if heavy rust is present)  
   • Exterior metal primer (look for “etching” or “rust-inhibitive” primer)  
   • Exterior metal paint—acrylic latex or solvent-based alkyd/enamel  
   • High-quality synthetic brush and/or ¼-inch nap roller; optional: HVLP or airless sprayer  
   • Painter’s tape, drop cloths, nitrile gloves, safety glasses, mask/respirator

3. Clear and protect the work area  
   • Move lawn tools, bikes, etc. away from the shed.  
   • Lay down drop cloths to catch chips and overspray.  
   • Mask hinges, door handles, windows, and the slab perimeter with painter’s tape.

4. Remove loose rust and paint  
   • Scrape any flaking paint with the wire brush.  
   • Follow with sanding—dull glossy areas so the primer can grip.  
   • Vacuum or brush away dust.

5. Degrease and wash  
   • Mix detergent with warm water; scrub the entire shed.  
   • Rinse thoroughly. Any residue left behind can cause peeling.  
   • Let the metal dry completely (1–2 hours in warm weather).

6. Treat rust (if needed)  
   • For pitted or stubborn rust, apply a rust converter per the label.  
   • It chemically neutralizes iron oxide and gives a primable surface.

7. Prime  
   • Stir (don’t shake) the primer to avoid bubbles.  
   • Apply one even coat with a brush/roller or spray.  
   • Pay extra attention to seams and edges—they’re rust hot spots.  
   • Allow the full recoat/curing time, usually 2–4 hours for acrylic primers, 24 hours for some alkyds.

8. Paint  
   • Stir the paint and strain it if you’ll be spraying.  
   • First coat: use long, even strokes; keep a wet edge to avoid lap marks.  
   • Let it dry. Lightly scuff with 220-grit between coats for best adhesion.  
   • Second coat: apply perpendicular to the first if rolling, or in a cross-hatch pattern if brushing.

9. Inspect and touch up  
   • Check for missed spots at fasteners, roof drip edges, and door jambs.  
   • Touch up while the paint is still fresh.

10. Cure and clean up  
   • The shed will be dry to the touch in a few hours but takes about a week to fully cure.  
   • Store leftover paint in an airtight can.  
   • Clean brushes with water (for acrylic) or mineral spirits (for alkyd).

Tips for longevity  
• Keep vegetation away from the base; trapped moisture accelerates corrosion.  
• Hose down dirt or bird droppings periodically; mild soap is fine.  
• If you nick the surface, dab on primer + paint right away—small repairs are easier than a full repaint.

With careful prep and quality products, a metal shed paint job should last 7–10 years before it needs more than a light refresher. Good luck with your project, and if you need primers, rust converters, or brushes, your local Zava store will have them on hand.

What's the best way to paint wrought iron?

Here’s a straightforward, time-tested workflow you can follow to get a smooth, durable finish on wrought iron railings, furniture, gates, or décor. Feel free to adjust product choices to match the brands you prefer or those available at your local Zava store.

1. Inspect and plan  
   • Check for structural damage or excessive corrosion—if it’s badly pitted or flaking, repair or replace the part first.  
   • If the piece was painted before 1978, assume the old coating could contain lead. In that case, follow EPA Renovate Right guidelines or hire a lead-certified pro.

2. Gather supplies  
   • Safety gear: gloves, safety glasses, dust mask or respirator (rated for paint fumes and dust).  
   • Drop cloths or plastic sheeting.  
   • Wire brush, sanding block (80–120 grit), and/or a drill with a wire-cup brush.  
   • Clean rags, detergent (or a degreasing cleaner like TSP substitute).  
   • Rust-inhibiting metal primer (oil-based or acrylic, “for ferrous metals” or “direct-to-rust”).  
   • Exterior-grade enamel or metal-specific paint (oil-based alkyd or high-quality acrylic urethane).  
   • Mineral spirits (if you’re using oil-based products) for cleanup.  
   • Good-quality natural-bristle (oil) or synthetic-bristle/foam brush (water-based). A small trim roller works for flat panels.

3. Surface prep (the most important step)  
   a. Remove loose paint and rust:  
      – Scrape off flaking paint.  
      – Wire-brush until you reach sound metal. Power-tool attachments speed this up but wear eye/ear protection.  
   b. Smooth edges: Sand any remaining paint ridges so you’re not priming over sharp “steps.”  
   c. Clean: Wash with warm water plus detergent or degreaser; rinse thoroughly. Oil, dirt, or salts will cause new paint to peel.  
   d. Dry completely: Iron holds moisture in crevices—wait at least a couple of hours, or quicker with a leaf blower or compressed air.

4. Apply rust-inhibiting primer  
   • Stir (don’t shake) the can to minimize bubbles.  
   • Brush/roll a thin, even coat, working into scrolls and tight joints.  
   • If rust was severe, use a “convert-and-prime” product that neutralizes residual rust.  
   • Let it cure per label—typically 4–24 h. Lightly scuff with 220 grit if more than 24 h passes before top-coating.

5. Paint  
   • Two light coats outperform one thick one: fewer runs, better adhesion.  
   • Maintain a wet edge; back-brush drips in crevices.  
   • Respect recoat times (usually 2–4 h water-based, 8–16 h oil-based).  
   • Final cure can take several days—avoid hard contact until fully hardened.

6. Optional clear coat  
   Some manufacturers offer a UV-stable clear enamel for extra gloss and fade resistance. Only apply if the color coat is designed to accept it.

7. Maintenance tips  
   • Inspect yearly for chips. Touch up promptly—small rust spots are easier than full re-painting.  
   • Clean with mild soap; avoid harsh abrasives that can scratch the finish.

• Work outdoors or in a well-ventilated garage; fumes from oil-based products are flammable.  
• Keep spark sources away; store rags in a sealed, water-filled container to prevent spontaneous combustion.  
• Dispose of solvents and used rags at a hazardous-waste collection site—local regulations differ.

How do I paint a room with textured walls?

Painting textured walls isn’t difficult, but it does call for a few special tools, extra paint, and a different technique than you’d use on smooth drywall. Follow these steps and you’ll get an even, long-lasting finish.

1. Gather your supplies  
   • Drop cloths or plastic sheeting  
   • Painter’s tape  
   • Soft-bristle broom or vacuum with brush attachment  
   • Mild detergent and sponge (for washing)  
   • Patch compound and putty knife (optional, for repairs)  
   • 2½–3″ angled sash brush  
   • ¾″ to 1¼″ nap roller covers (the rougher the texture, the thicker the nap)  
   • Sturdy roller frame and extension pole  
   • High-quality acrylic/latex primer (use stain-blocking primer if needed)  
   • Interior paint (buy 10–15 % more than usual; texture increases surface area)  
   • Paint tray or bucket/grid  
   • Ladder, safety glasses, gloves, and respirator or N95 mask (if sanding or working in tight spaces)

2. Prepare the room  
   • Move furniture to the center and cover it; protect floors with drop cloths.  
   • Mask off trim, windows, and outlets with painter’s tape.  
   • Good lighting helps you spot missed spots on textured surfaces—set up work lights if necessary.

3. Clean the walls  
   • Dust or vacuum to remove cobwebs and debris caught in the texture.  
   • Wash greasy or high-traffic areas with a mild detergent solution, then rinse with clean water.  
   • Let walls dry completely before priming.

4. Repair and caulk (optional)  
   • Fill small divots or nail holes with patch compound; match the surrounding texture as best as possible.  
   • Lightly sand any high ridges or patch edges. Wipe the surface clean.  
   • Caulk gaps where trim meets the wall.

5. Prime  
   • Use a high-quality primer suited to your paint type (for most latex paints, use latex primer).  
   • Cut in edges with the sash brush.  
   • Roll the primer with a thick-nap roller: work in 3-x-3 ft sections, using a “W” or “M” pattern to push primer into the low spots.  
   • Feather out edges to avoid lap lines.  
   • Allow primer to dry fully (check label—usually 1–4 hours).

6. Inspect  
   • After priming, shine a light across the surface. Touch up any missed crevices or thin spots.

7. Paint  
   • Stir paint thoroughly and pour into tray or bucket with grid.  
   • Cut in around the ceiling line, corners, and baseboards first.  
   • Roll the paint using the same “W” pattern. Apply firm, even pressure so the roller nap gets into the recesses.  
   • Maintain a wet edge: overlap each pass slightly and avoid stopping mid-wall.  
   • On highly textured walls (e.g., knockdown or heavy orange-peel), back-roll gently after each section: run the roller lightly over the area in one direction to even out stipple marks.  
   • Let the first coat dry, then inspect. A second coat is typical on textured surfaces; a third may be needed for drastic color changes.

8. Finishing touches  
   • Remove tape while the last coat is still slightly tacky to minimize peeling.  
   • Reinstall outlet covers and hardware when paint is fully dry.  
   • Clean brushes and rollers immediately (warm soapy water for water-based paint).  
   • Store touch-up paint labeled by room and date.

Helpful tips  
   • Roller naps: ¾″ is fine for light orange-peel; 1″–1¼″ works best on knockdown, popcorn, or stucco-like textures.  
   • If paint still doesn’t reach recesses, try a specialty “texture roller” or a mini‐roller to dab specific spots.  
   • Use sheen to your advantage: flat or eggshell hides imperfections; satin or semi-gloss is scrubbable but highlights texture.  
   • Work at comfortable shoulder height by using an extension pole rather than a ladder for large wall areas.

   • Keep paint and tools away from children and pets.  
   • Dispose of used rags and paint cans per local regulations.

With patience and the right roller nap, textured walls can look just as crisp and uniform as smooth drywall. Enjoy your refreshed space!

What's the most durable paint tray?

When you’re looking for a paint tray that will stand up to repeated use, focus on three things: the material, the gauge (thickness) of that material, and how easily you can clean or line the tray.

1. Galvanised‐steel trays  
   • Durability: Highest. Galvanised steel resists rust and dents far better than standard mild-steel trays.  
   • Thickness matters: Aim for 0.6- to 0.8-mm sheet steel; thinner trays flex and eventually crease.  
   • Downside: Heavier and a little more expensive.  

2. Solvent-resistant polypropylene (rigid plastic) trays  
   • Durability: Very good, provided the plastic is solvent resistant. Look for trays labelled “PP” or “polypropylene” rather than generic “plastic.”  
   • Key benefit: Lightweight and won’t rust.  
   • Downside: Can crack if you drop them on concrete in cold weather.  

3. High-density polyethylene (HDPE) trays  
   • Durability: Good for water-based paints, but HDPE is less solvent-resistant than polypropylene.  
   • Tip: If you use only latex/acrylic paints, an HDPE tray with disposable liners can last a long time.  

4. Aluminium trays  
   • Durability: Moderate. Aluminium won’t rust, but it bends more easily than steel. Useful if you need something lighter than steel but more rigid than plastic.  

Top pick from Zava’s range  
• Zava Pro-Build Galvanised Steel Tray, 9-inch: 0.7-mm galvanised sheet, reinforced ribs, and a folded wire handle. Built for contractors—customers typically get several years out of one tray.  
• Runner-up: Zava Solvent-Safe Poly Tray, 9-inch: Injection-moulded polypropylene, integrated brush rest, and chemical-resistant to common paint strippers.

Maintenance tips to maximise life  
1. Use disposable liners for quick colour change and to keep the tray’s surface intact.  
2. If you skip liners, rinse immediately after each session—dried-on paint is what eventually weakens seams and ridges.  
3. For steel trays, allow them to dry fully before stacking to avoid trapped moisture.  

In short: a galvanised-steel tray is the most durable overall. If you prefer something lighter, go for a solvent-resistant polypropylene tray and use liners to get comparable longevity.

What primer should I use for heavily stained walls?

When walls have heavy staining—water marks, smoke damage, crayon, marker, tannin bleed-through from wood, etc.—you need a “high-hide” or “stain-blocking” primer that can both seal the stain and prevent it from bleeding through your new topcoat. Look for one (or more) of the following qualities:

1. Shellac-based stain blocker  
   • Fast drying (15–60 min recoats)  
   • Excellent at locking in water, smoke, nicotine, tannin, and ink stains  
   • Odor is strong, so use good ventilation and a proper respirator if possible  
   • Cleanup with denatured alcohol (not water)  
   Popular examples: Zinsser B-I-N®; Rust-Oleum® Shellac-Base Primer.

2. Solvent/oil-based stain-blocking primer  
   • Very good at stopping water stains, graffiti, knots, tannins, grease, smoke, etc.  
   • Longer dry time (1–4 hrs to recoat) and stronger odor than latex.  
   • Cleanup with mineral spirits.  
   Popular examples: Zinsser Cover-Stain®, Kilz Original®, Sherwin-Williams ProBlock® Oil.

3. High-quality water-based “hybrid” stain blocker  
   • Newer acrylic formulas combine stain-blocking with low odor and easy water cleanup.  
   • Works well for light-to-moderate stains; for the worst smoke or water damage shellac is still best.  
   Popular examples: Zinsser Bulls Eye 1-2-3® Plus, Kilz 3® Premium, Benjamin Moore Fresh Start® High-Hide.

Choosing the right one:  
• For severe smoke or water damage: go straight to a shellac primer for maximum blocking.  
• For large areas where odor and cleanup matter (e.g., occupied homes): consider a high-end acrylic blocker, but spot-prime stubborn stains with shellac.  
• For wood knots or cedar bleed: shellac or a dedicated alkyd stain blocker.  
• For crayon, marker, lipstick: a quick coat of shellac or oil primer will lock it in.

Tips for best results  
1. Clean the surface first. Scrub off soot, grease, loose material, and let walls dry completely.  
2. Stir primer thoroughly; don’t thin unless the label allows it.  
3. Apply with a high-quality roller or brush rated for solvent if using shellac/oil.  
4. Follow the manufacturer’s dry-time and recoat window.  
5. After priming, check for any stain “shadows.” If they show, apply a second primer coat before topcoat.

What's the best way to paint over rust?

Painting over rust can be done successfully if you remove or stabilize the corrosion first and create a sound surface for the new finish. Here’s a practical, step-by-step approach:

1. Assess the rust.
   • Light surface rust (a thin, flaky layer) can often be cleaned and primed.
   • Heavy, pitted rust may need more aggressive removal or part replacement.

2. Gather supplies.
   • Safety gear: goggles, dust mask or respirator, gloves.
   • Wire brush or wire-wheel drill attachment.
   • Medium-grit sandpaper (80–120 grit).
   • Rust converter or rust-inhibiting primer (labeled “for direct-to-rust” or “rust-converting”).
   • Clean rags and a degreasing cleaner.
   • High-quality paint suitable for the material (e.g., metal enamel or outdoor acrylic).
   • Paintbrush, foam brush, or spray can, depending on project size.

3. Remove loose rust and paint.
   • Scrub with a wire brush to knock off flakes.
   • Sand the area until the remaining rust feels smooth and the edges of any intact paint are feathered.

4. Clean thoroughly.
   • Wipe away dust with a clean rag.
   • Degrease with a mild solvent or household degreasing cleaner.
   • Let it dry completely—paint won’t adhere to damp or oily surfaces.

5. Stabilize or convert any remaining rust.
   • For light residual rust: Apply a rust converter product. It chemically changes iron oxide into a paintable, inert layer.
   • Follow the product’s dwell time and recoat instructions.

6. Prime.
   • Use a rust-inhibiting metal primer, even if you used a converter (many converters double as primers, but check the label).
   • Apply in thin, even coats. Allow full drying/curing time between coats.

7. Paint.
   • Choose a paint compatible with the primer (often indicated on the can).
   • Apply at least two thin coats, allowing the recommended drying time.
   • For outdoor metal, a protective enamel or industrial-grade acrylic offers the best durability.

8. Optional topcoat.
   • If extra protection is needed (e.g., on outdoor furniture), add a clear coat formulated for metal after the paint cures.

Tips:
• Work in a well-ventilated area or outdoors.
• Keep an eye on weather conditions; temperature and humidity affect drying times.
• If rust is severe and structural strength is compromised, replacement or professional repair is safer.

With careful prep and the right products, painted metal can look great and resist rust for years. Good luck with your project—and if you need specific primers or paints, Zava’s staff can point you to compatible options.
